channel.description: Master of I.T in UKM. Loves to eat, code, talk. Enjoy Reading Peeks !

item.title: About This Blog & Future
item.description:
This Blog is friendly made via Jekyll which allows possible static blog-aware sites. In this blog, the post will be categorized according tags

  • Personal
  • Web
  • Mobile

item.title: Going Progressive - Beyond Mobile Experience
item.description:
Building a great web app is always ultimate utopia to be achieved by us developers. Web with great experience attracts and acquires users to be back to our site and learn more.

Few years ago, we haven’t heard terms of Responsive or Performance/Speed in building sites. We just don’t care, we just build how it looks. But now, the requirements and user demands have gone up, and developers have to learn more to make the web fast and accessible by anyone.

In order to produce great web experience, Google Developers have released a tutorial portal to produce Progressive Web App (PWA). Link Here

What is PWA ?

Progressive Web Apps use modern web capabilities to deliver an app-like user experience. They evolve from pages in browser tabs to immersive, top-level apps, maintaining the web’s low friction at every moment.

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
